Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: RAPID: Using river restoration to test the ecological and evolutionary effects of secondary contact
Award.AbstractNarration:
In many aquatic ecosystems, dams have isolated fish populations for decades to centuries and the isolated populations have diverged both morphologically and genetically. Secondary contact between previously isolated populations will occur as these dams are removed or restoration efforts restore spatial connectivity. This RAPID project will examine the ecological and evolutionary consequences of the initial stages of secondary contact; restoration of river connectivity will soon allow secondary contact between anadromous alewife populations and landlocked populations in Rogers Lake, Connecticut. Divergence in morphology, foraging behavior, and migration has altered the ecological role of these two alewife life history forms over the past 250-350 years. Research will examine the inbreeding between anadromous and landlocked alewife using genetic markers to track introgression. It will document changes in food web structure, nutrient loading, and habitat and resource use by alewife at the initiation of secondary contact. By documenting these important direct and indirect effects of initial contact between anadromous and landlocked populations, the project will significantly advance our understanding of a process that is fundamental to the origin and maintenance of biodiversity.

Although anadromous alewives are a critical resource in freshwater and marine habitats and a federally listed species of conservation concern, landlocked alewives are invasive across their range. The investigators will continue work with local lake associations, land trusts and the regional conservation and management community to aid anadromous alewife restoration efforts by contributing results from this study. They will take advantage of an NIH-funded Yale program to recruit under-represented minority undergraduate students to the project, and will train them in the broader scientific context of the research, research methods, data analysis, and written and oral project reports. Outreach talks to the general public, education programs targeting underrepresented minority groups, interactive displays, and digital outreach via internet and social media are also planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Populations of organisms are regularly isolated by natural processes and human activities. In isolation, populations can adapt to local environments, creating ecologically important variation that can change the role of the population within its ecosystem. Natural processes and human activities can also cause populations that have diverged to come back into contact - a process called secondary contact. The outcome of secondary contact is important for understanding how populations evolve and how ecosystems function. This project used the restoration of river connectivity to study the ecological and evolutionary consequences of the initial stages of secondary contact between previously isolated populations of alewife, Alosa pseudoharengus. Alewife is an ecologically important fish in coastal freshwater and marine ecosystems across eastern North America. A restoration project initiated in 2014 (a fishway installed on a dam) allowed migratory anadromous alewife to access historical spawning grounds in Rogers Lake, CT, where they came into contact with a resident landlocked alewife population.

This project documented the number of anadromous alewife entering Rogers Lake, developed the genetic markers required to estimate reproduction and gene flow between anadromous and landlocked populations, measured the potential for seasonal overlap in spawning by anadromous and landlocked populations, and collected the pre- and post-restoration data required to track the long-term ecological and evolutionary dynamics of secondary contact.

This project has informed the conservation and management of anadromous alewife, a critical resource in coastal freshwater and marine habitats, a federally listed species of conservation concern, and the focus of intensive restoration and conservation efforts. The genomic tools developed by this project represent a novel tool to help resource managers better address important questions, such as the impact of landlocked alewife populations on the restoration of anadromous runs and the effects of marine bycatch on specific anadromous alewife populations. It has trained two graduate students and three undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented backgrounds, in a unique combination of advanced genomics techniques, whole lake sampling, and manipulative field experiments. The PIs have worked with a local lake association and a land trust to address the ecological consequences of anadromous alewife restoration, and with regional managers to provide science to inform anadromous alewife recovery.
